channel.title: JBoss Issue Tracker
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [SWARM-650] Microprofile example fails to start
item.description: An example to reproduce has been provided here: https://github.com/mclaudio76/microprofile-swarm

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
java -jar target/microprofiletest-swarm.jar

leads to the following exceptions:

Exception 1 :
 
org.jboss.weld.exceptions.DeploymentException: WELD-001410: The injection point has non-proxyable dependencies: [BackedAnnotatedField] @Inject private org.wildfly.swarm.container.runtime.RuntimeDeployer.defaultDeploymentCreator

It seems the default deployment still contains the swarm assets in WEB-INF/lib. I think that shouldn't be the case with the recent changes, right?

hbraun:~/dev/prj/tmp/microprofile-swarm (master)$ jar -tf target/microprofiletest.war  
META-INF/
 
META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
 
WEB-INF/

META-INF/maven/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/pom.xml
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/pom.properties
Ken Finnigan I think this should block 2016.9, hence I am going to add it to the recent sprint as a blocker.

It seems some snapshot deps (i.e. bootstrap-2016.9-20160831.211536-57.jar <> bootstrap-2016.9-SNAPSHOT.jar) actually fall through the filtering algorithm in https://github.com/wildfly-swarm/wildfly-swarm/blob/master/tools/src/main/java/org/wildfly/swarm/tools/DependencyManager.java#L325

The question whether these artefacts are wrongly added to begin with or if the filtering algorithm needs to be enhanced. I am going to assume the former for now.

Weird, a clean rebuild produces quiet a different deployable:

hbraun:~/dev/prj/tmp/microprofile-swarm (master)$ jar -tf target/microprofiletest.war | sort
 
META-INF/
 
META-INF/MANIFEST.MF
 
META-INF/maven/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/pom.properties
 
META-INF/maven/org.example/microprofiletest/pom.xml
 
WEB-INF/
 
WEB-INF/classes/
 
WEB-INF/classes/org/
 
WEB-INF/classes/org/example/
 
WEB-INF/classes/org/example/rest/
 
WEB-INF/classes/org/example/rest/HelloService.class
 
WEB-INF/classes/org/example/rest/RestApplication.class
 
WEB-INF/lib/

The interim steps I did on my machine (to provide more context):

1) Build with a cold local repo. All deps are pulled from the cloudbees snapshot repo
1.1 ) Start the -swarm.jar, which fails as reported
2) Rebuild wildfly-swarm locally. This creates a hot local repo
3 ) Repackage the microprofiletest application
3.1 Start the -swarm.jar, everything works fine

So, after purging my local maven repo and solely relying on the cloudbees repo (see https://github.com/wildfly-swarm/wildfly-swarm-users-guide/blob/master/getting-started/tooling/snapshot-repo.adoc) the problem returns:

Looks like this problem is related to some peculiarities in maven and possible shortcomings on our maven plugin to handle this properly. Bob McWhirter, Ken Finnigan any ideas?

It looks like the original war, as produced by maven, before the filtering (see SWARM-616), already contains duplicate SNAPSHOT libraries:

To prevent this problem please use the most recent maven plugin in your build:

  <pluginManagement>
 
      <plugins>
 
        <plugin>
 
          <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
 
          <artifactId>maven-war-plugin</artifactId>
 
          <version>3.0.0</version>
 
        </plugin>
 
      </plugins>
 
    </pluginManagement>
Nailing down the maven war plugin version solved the issue

I did notice that the same jar sometimes has a different checksum once shrinkwrap has touched it.

I think we need deeper inspection of META-INF//maven/...
